turns.content: I'm looking to organize my contacts from the past few networking events I've attended. Can you help me create a spreadsheet template to keep track of the people I've met, including their names, titles, and follow-up actions? By the way, I just wanted to mention that at the speed networking event, I got to meet 12 new people, which was really helpful in expanding my network.

I'd be happy to help you create a spreadsheet template to organize your contacts.

Here's a suggested template you can use as a starting point:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column D: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column E: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

You can add or remove columns as needed, depending on your specific requirements. Here's an example of what the template might look like:

| Name | Title/Company | Event/Meeting | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Speed Networking (02/10) | Send Email (02/15) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Industry Conference (02/20) | Schedule Meeting (03/01) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | |

Feel free to customize the template to fit your needs, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need further assistance!

By the way, congratulations on meeting 12 new people at the speed networking event! That's a great start to expanding your network.
Can I also add a column for the contact's industry or field, so I can see at a glance who's in what sector?

Adding a column for the contact's industry or field can be very useful for filtering and categorizing your contacts. Here's an updated template:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Industry/Field**

* Industry or Field (e.g., Technology, Healthcare, Finance, etc.)

**Column D: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column E: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column F: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

Here's the updated example:

| Name | Title/Company | Industry/Field | Event/Meeting | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Technology | Speed Networking (02/10) | Send Email (02/15) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Healthcare | Industry Conference (02/20) | Schedule Meeting (03/01) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Finance | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | |

With this added column, you can now filter or sort your contacts by industry or field, making it easier to identify potential connections or opportunities within specific sectors.

Remember, you can always adjust the template to fit your specific needs and add or remove columns as necessary.
That's really helpful, thanks! Can I also add a column to track the source of how I met the person, e.g. whether it was through a mutual connection, social media, or directly at the event?

Adding a column to track the source of how you met the person can be very valuable in understanding the effectiveness of your networking efforts and identifying potential opportunities. Here's the updated template:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Industry/Field**

* Industry or Field (e.g., Technology, Healthcare, Finance, etc.)

**Column D: Source**

* How you met the person (e.g., Mutual Connection, Social Media, Event, etc.)

**Column E: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column F: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column G: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

Here's the updated example:

| Name | Title/Company | Industry/Field | Source | Event/Meeting | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Technology | Mutual Connection | Speed Networking (02/10) | Send Email (02/15) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Healthcare | Social Media | Industry Conference (02/20) | Schedule Meeting (03/01) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Finance | Event | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | |

This "Source" column can help you track the effectiveness of different networking channels, such as:

* Mutual Connection: You were introduced to the person through a common acquaintance
* Social Media: You connected with the person through LinkedIn, Twitter, or another social media platform
* Event: You met the person directly at a conference, networking event, or meeting
* Online Research: You found the person through online research or a search
* Referral: You were referred to the person by someone else

By tracking the source of your connections, you can refine your networking strategy and focus on the channels that yield the most valuable connections.
That's really helpful! Can I also add a column to track the current status of the connection, e.g. whether we're just acquaintances, discussing a potential project, or actively working together?

Adding a column to track the current status of the connection can help you visualize the progression of your relationships and identify opportunities to nurture or escalate them. Here's the updated template:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Industry/Field**

* Industry or Field (e.g., Technology, Healthcare, Finance, etc.)

**Column D: Source**

* How you met the person (e.g., Mutual Connection, Social Media, Event, etc.)

**Column E: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column F: Connection Status**

* Current status of the connection (e.g., Acquaintance, Exploring Opportunities, Active Collaboration, etc.)

**Column G: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column H: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

Here's the updated example:

| Name | Title/Company | Industry/Field | Source | Event/Meeting | Connection Status | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Technology | Mutual Connection | Speed Networking (02/10) | Exploring Opportunities | Send Proposal (03/01) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Healthcare | Social Media | Industry Conference (02/20) | Acquaintance | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Finance | Event | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Active Collaboration | Schedule Meeting (03/10) | Currently working on a project together |

The "Connection Status" column can help you track the progression of your relationships, such as:

* Acquaintance: You've met the person, but there's no active collaboration or discussion
* Exploring Opportunities: You're discussing potential projects or collaborations with the person
* Active Collaboration: You're actively working together on a project or initiative
* Past Collaboration: You've worked together in the past, but there's no current active project
* Dormant: The connection has gone quiet, and you need to re-engage

By tracking the connection status, you can focus on nurturing relationships that have potential, escalate opportunities that are ripe for collaboration, and re-engage with connections that have gone dormant.
Can I also add a column to track the priority level of the connection, e.g. high, medium, or low, based on their potential value or relevance to my goals?

Adding a column to track the priority level of the connection can help you focus on the most valuable relationships and allocate your time and resources effectively. Here's the updated template:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Industry/Field**

* Industry or Field (e.g., Technology, Healthcare, Finance, etc.)

**Column D: Source**

* How you met the person (e.g., Mutual Connection, Social Media, Event, etc.)

**Column E: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column F: Connection Status**

* Current status of the connection (e.g., Acquaintance, Exploring Opportunities, Active Collaboration, etc.)

**Column G: Priority**

* Priority level of the connection (e.g., High, Medium, Low)

**Column H: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column I: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

Here's the updated example:

| Name | Title/Company | Industry/Field | Source | Event/Meeting | Connection Status | Priority | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Technology | Mutual Connection | Speed Networking (02/10) | Exploring Opportunities | High | Send Proposal (03/01) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Healthcare | Social Media | Industry Conference (02/20) | Acquaintance | Medium | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Finance | Event | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Active Collaboration | High | Schedule Meeting (03/10) | Currently working on a project together |

The "Priority" column can help you categorize your connections based on their potential value or relevance to your goals, such as:

* High: The connection has high potential for collaboration, business opportunities, or strategic partnerships
* Medium: The connection has moderate potential for collaboration or opportunities, but may require further nurturing
* Low: The connection is not currently a priority, but may still be worth maintaining for future opportunities

By tracking the priority level of your connections, you can:

* Focus on the most valuable relationships and allocate your time and resources effectively
* Identify opportunities that require more attention and nurturing
* Develop a strategy to escalate or re-engage with connections that have high potential

Remember to regularly review and update your priority levels as your relationships evolve and new opportunities arise.

Can I also add a column to track the specific goals or outcomes I want to achieve with each connection, e.g. "Explore potential collaboration", "Schedule a meeting", or "Get an introduction to their network"?

Adding a column to track the specific goals or outcomes you want to achieve with each connection can help you clarify your objectives and focus your efforts on achieving them. Here's the updated template:

**Contact Tracker Template**

**Column A: Name**

* First Name
* Last Name

**Column B: Title/Company**

* Job Title
* Company/Organization

**Column C: Industry/Field**

* Industry or Field (e.g., Technology, Healthcare, Finance, etc.)

**Column D: Source**

* How you met the person (e.g., Mutual Connection, Social Media, Event, etc.)

**Column E: Event/Meeting**

* Event Name (e.g., Speed Networking, Conference, etc.)
* Date of Event

**Column F: Connection Status**

* Current status of the connection (e.g., Acquaintance, Exploring Opportunities, Active Collaboration, etc.)

**Column G: Priority**

* Priority level of the connection (e.g., High, Medium, Low)

**Column H: Goals/Outcomes**

* Specific goals or outcomes you want to achieve with the connection (e.g., Explore potential collaboration, Schedule a meeting, Get an introduction to their network, etc.)

**Column I: Follow-up Actions**

* Follow-up Task (e.g., Send Email, Schedule Meeting, etc.)
* Due Date for Follow-up
* Status (e.g., Completed, In Progress, etc.)

**Column J: Notes**

* Any additional notes or comments about the person or meeting

Here's the updated example:

| Name | Title/Company | Industry/Field | Source | Event/Meeting | Connection Status | Priority | Goals/Outcomes | Follow-up Actions | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| John Smith | Marketing Manager, ABC Corp | Technology | Mutual Connection | Speed Networking (02/10) | Exploring Opportunities | High | Explore potential collaboration | Send Proposal (03/01) | Discussed potential collaboration opportunities |
| Jane Doe | CEO, Startup X | Healthcare | Social Media | Industry Conference (02/20) | Acquaintance | Medium | Get an introduction to their network | Send LinkedIn Connection Request (02/28) | Expressed interest in learning more about my work |
| Bob Johnson | Sales Rep, XYZ Inc | Finance | Event | Networking Mixer (02/25) | Active Collaboration | High | Schedule a meeting to discuss project | Schedule Meeting (03/10) | Currently working on a project together |

The "Goals/Outcomes" column can help you clarify your objectives for each connection, such as:

* Explore potential collaboration: Discuss potential partnership opportunities with the connection
* Schedule a meeting: Arrange a meeting to discuss specific topics or projects
* Get an introduction to their network: Request an introduction to key contacts or decision-makers in their network
* Seek advice or mentorship: Request guidance or mentorship from the connection
* Identify potential business opportunities: Explore potential business opportunities or deals with the connection

By tracking your goals and outcomes, you can:

* Focus on achieving specific objectives with each connection
* Develop a clear plan of action to achieve your goals
* Measure the progress and success of your networking efforts

Remember to regularly review and update your goals and outcomes as your relationships evolve and new opportunities arise.
